interlinear-text.item: GSK La Reine aux Cheveux longs de Quarante Gazes

phrase.item: There was once a king and he had four sons.
There were three sons from one mother and one son from a different mother.
The three sons were beloved but the one was despised.
One day the king said to a servant: "Hey you, go to my sons' roof --why they are complaining?"
She went [and saw] that the three beloved sons were sleeping while the despised one was complaining to his mother: "If only my father would send us to bring back the pearl that shines at night!"

The servant came back and said, "The three beloved sons are sleeping, the despised one is complaining to his mother, saying: "My father is not letting us go and bring back the pearl that shines at night." He [the father] said: "He is nothing but a filthy scoundrel."
He said: "I will send my three beloved sons."
In the morning he requested food for the journey and blackberry meal to be cooked for them.
The despised son came [to say] that he also wanted to go.
They didn't give him any food for the journey or blackberry meal, only a nasty wound.
He went following his brothers.
They passed several steppes and deserts and reached a fork in the road. On a stone it was written: by one road you will not return, by the other road you will return.
There were two roads. The three beloved sons went by the road [labeled] "you will return" and they sent the despised one down the road [labeled] "you will not return."
He went and passed several steppes and deserts, and reached a place where he became very thirsty.
He reached a spring and drank water from that spring.
He was very thankful. He got up from that place and set off; he passed several other deserts and reached a place with many livstock.
He said: "Hey, shepherd!"
"Whose livestock are these?"
He said: "The black devil's."
He said: "Give me a lamb, I am very hungry!"
"I will slaughter and eat it!" He [the shepherd] said, "I cannot give you any!" He [the boy] grabbed a lamb by force and slaughtered it.
He cooked it all, ate it and set off again.
Again he crossed several steppes and deserts and reached a place.
He said: "This place and castle, whose are they?"
They replied: "This is the black devil's," He entered the black devil's castle and saw a fairy siting there.
She said: "Young man!"
"I feel bad for you, you should leave [this place]!"
He said: "I will not leave." She said, "If you need bread, come in."
"The cauldron is full."
He entered [and saw] seven bronze cauldrons on the fire.
He ate from all seven bronze caudrons, left through the back way, and went to the fairy.
The fairy said to him: "How much did you eat?"
He said: "All seven cauldrons I ate." She said: "Ah, you ate more than the devil--now what shall I do for him?"
He said: "What happens when the devil comes?"
She said: "When the devil comes the world trembles and the air darkens."
He said: "When he reaches the gate, what is it like?"
She said: "Like fire is jumping out of his mouth!"
The king's son drew [his] sword and hid by the gate.
When the devil came, he said: "Ah!"
"It smells like a person in the soil--if you are [made of] soil, I will turn you to soil, if you are [made of] wind, I will blow you away."
When he [the devil] entered, the king's son struck him with the sword and he fell.
Then the king's son enters the fairy['s room]. She said: "O prince!"
"You are very shameless!"
"I told you to leave, you didn't leave, and now the devil is about to come!"
The king's son said: "I have killed the devil."
She said: "Stop joking."
He said: "Go and see!"
She said: "All right!"
She went out and saw the devil fallen [on the ground]. She said: "O prince!"
"The devil used to take care of me, now you should stay!"
He said: "I am going in the service of my father."
She said: "What service are you going for?"
He said: "I am going for the white falcon." She said: "Oh, you are very brainless!"
"From there not even your dead body will escape!"
He said: "I trust in God and will go!"

She said: "I will not let you go." He said: "I will come back." She said: " A sister of mine is married to the white devil." He set off, crossing several deserts, until he reached the white devil's flock.
He said to the shepherd: "Give me a lamb to slaughter." The shepherd said: "Did you know that this flock belongs to the white devil?"
He said: "Give me a lamb to slaughter, and fuck the white devil."
The shepherd refused. He [the prince] took a rope, tied up his hands and feet and threw him there.
He took a lamb and slaughtered it.
Then he cooked and ate it.
He untied his [the shepherd's] feet and arms and said: "Go wherever you want, it's up to you!"
He set off and enters the white devil's castle, [where he saw] a fairy sitting there. She said: "Young man, you were wrong to come into this castle--the white devil is about to appear."
He said: "What do I have to do with the white devil's abuse?"
"I need something to eat."
She said: "Come in, I have filled the cauldron already for the devil."
"You can eat as much as you want."
He entered [and saw] that there were seven full cauldrons full; he ate it all and came out to the fairy.
The fairy said to him: "How much did you eat?"
He said: "Whatever was there, I ate." She said: "You are an evil spirit for having eaten everything!"
She said: "Leave, go!"
"When the white devil comes, he will kill us both."
He said: "What is it like when he comes?"
She said: "When he comes, the whole world is covered in dust."
He didn't leave: he dug a pit by the gate and hid himself inside.
The devil appears and said: "A mortal man has been here!"
He had just entered when [the prince] struck him with sword and he fell. He [the prince] got up and left and went to the fairy.
The fairy said to him: "Oh, you are very shameless!"
He said: "Why?"
She said: "Now the devil is coming and he'll eat you and me both." He said: "I have killed him." She said: "Stop lying!"
He said: "Go out [and see]!"
She went out [and saw] he was dead.
She said: "O prince!"
"The devil used to take care of me, now what shall I do?"
She said: "You'll stay with me!"
He said: "I am going in my father's service, I cannot stay with you now."
[As] he left, she said: "A sister of mine is married to the red devil."
He reached the red devil's flock where it grazed.
He takes one lamb, slaughtered it, and ate it.
He went and reached the red devil's gate [and saw] him standing by his gate.
They fought with each other; the king's son struck and killed him, and then went in to the fairy.
The fairy told him: "Young man, the red devil is coming now and will eat you."
He said: "I have killed the red devil".
She said: "Stop lying!"
He said: "Go and check him!"
She came [and saw] that he had killed him.
Right away she seized him, [saying]: "Stay with me!"
He said: "I cannot stay, I am going in my father's service."
She said: "Where are you going in your father's service?"
He said: "I am going to get the white falcon."
She said: "O prince!"
"You are very brainless!"
"From there not even your dead body will escape!"
He said: "I am going in my father's service, I will go." She said: "From here to there there are many more devils!"
He said: "Now what should I do?"
She said: "When you leave, you will pass several deserts, and there is [a legendary phoenix], Simurgh.
"She lays her eggs every year on the edge of a pool, on top of a sycamore."
"And every year a dragon swallows them."
"Now you go and kill the dragon, then Simurgh will take you to the Mount Qof .'
The prince left, crossing several steppes and deserts, and reached the edge of that pool.
He dug a pit, covered it with dry branches, and got inside the pit.
In the evening, [people] were bringing forty sets of nine breads, the meat of forty lambs, and young girl. [I.e. for a wedding]
He [the prince] came out and said: "Hey brothers!"
"What is happening here?"
They said: "This food and the king's daughter are all for the dragon this evening."
He said: "What if I kill the dragon?"
They said: "This kingdom will be yours."
The prince approached the king's daughter and said: "O princess!"
"I am feeling sleepy--I will put my head on your lap, but when the dragon comes let me know!"
The king's daughter said: "Very well, I will let you know."
They sat down and he fell so asleep that the king's daughter couldn't wake him.
The dragon's head appeared, the king's daughter shed a tear on his face.
He jumped up [and saw] that the dragon's head has appeared.
He struck him on the head with his sword.
The head fell off.
He [the dragon] said: "That head was not from my body." The king's son said: "That sword was not from my sheath."
Another head [of the dragon] came out, and he struck him again.
He said: "That head was not part of my body."
He said: "That sword was not from my sheath."
Then a third [head] came out, and he struck him again.
With the third head cut off, he [the dragon] emerged from the pool--he was the size of a mountain!
[The dragon] died.
They took the good news to the king that the dragon had been killed.
He said: "Who killed him?"
They said: "A prince."
He said: "Bring the prince here, I will give him my kingdom."
The prince was brought and he [the king] said: "O prince!"
"I want you to marry my daughter and will give you the kingdom as well."

He said: "I have come in my father's service, your daughter is a sister to me." He asked permission from the king and left. He went to the water and saw that the phoenix Simurgh had appeared. She said: "I smell a mortal man."
"If I find an earth-man I will tear him to pieces."
Her children said to her: "Mother, a mortal man saved us from the dragon."
She said: "Where is the earth-man now?"
Her children told her: "He is in that pit."
Simurgh came and took the king's son from the pit. Slowly she held him on her wing and took him to her house, saying: "O prince!"
"What is your wish?"
He said: "This is my wish: to go seek the white falcon and the pearl that shines at night."
She said: "Oh, prince!"
"You have done so much good for me!"
"Now find me forty fried lambs, find me forty [loaves of] bread, and take forty cups of water."

The king's son went and brought fourty lambs, forty [loaves of] bread, and forty cups of water. He put them on her wing and climbed up on her wing himself as well, and they left. They rose to the highest sky, and when they get close [Simurgh] said: "O prince, how does the world look to you?"
He said: "The size of a sieve." and they went on. She said, "How does the world look to you?"
He he said: "The size of a needle's point."
She said: "Put my meat into my mouth!"
He said: "The meat is finished."
She brought him back to the same place.
She said: "Prince, you could not feed me!"
Again the king's son went, and gathered again forty lambs, forty [loaves of] bread, forty cups of water, and put them again on her wing, and left again.
Again she said: "O prince!'
"How does the world look to you?"
He said: "The size of a sieve."
They went again and she said: "How does the world look to you?"
He said: "The size of a needle's point." She said: "Give me meat!"
[Since] the meat was gone, he cut off a piece of his thumb and put it in her mouth, and she set him down on the mountain of Qof. She said: "O prince!"
"Here is my good turn for you."
"When you gave me meat that last time, it was very tasty."
"What kind of meat was that?"
He said: "Lamb's meat."
She said: "No, it wasn't lamb's meat."
He didn't have any choice, so he said to Simurgh: "I cut my thumb."
She regurgitated and reattached it, [saying]: "You have done me a great service: every year I would try to hatch my chicks and the dragon would eat them. Now you have released us."
"[And] now I have brought you to Mount Qof."
The prince said: "What should I do?"
She said: "Now you go, and on the day when your task is complete I will come here and take you back down."
"There is another piece of advice I should give you, since you are inexperienced!"
"You are going, [but] how will you find the white falcon and bring back the pearl that shines at night?"
He said: "I don't know."
She said: "The pearl that shines at night and the white falcon are [in the home of] in the queen with forty-meter hair."
"She is on Mount Qof."
"The queen with forty-meter hair has many signs."
He said: "What are her signs?"
She said: "She has one garden that's full of flowers and another garden completely dry."
"Tell the parched garden: 'You are flowering!'"
"Tell the flowering garden, 'You are parched!'"
"Divert the water from flowering side and open it to the parched side."
"Go from there and you will come to a bridge."
"She called it the crooked bridge."
"As you pass it say: 'O straight bridge!'"
"When you pass it a gate will appear."
"The queen with forty-meter hair calls it the crooked gate."
“You will say: ‘What a straight gate!’"
"When you pass it all, [you will see] she has a horse and a dog of almond blossoms."
“There is grass in front of the dog and bones in front of the horse.”
“Take the grass and put it in front of the horse; take the bone and put it in front of the dog.”
“When you go from there and are about to enter the castle, [remember that] the queen with forty-meter hair when she sleeps has open eyes, and when she wakes her eyes are closed.”
“Her hair is forty meters long and she has forty pillars in her house.”
“Take her hair and fasten it to these forty pillars.”
“She has one pearl at the head [of her bed] and one pearl at the foot.”
“Take the one at the foot and place it by the head, and take the one at the head and blace it at the foot.”
She is wearing forty pairs of pants.
“Take off the pants on top and put them on underneath, and put the ones that were underneath on top.”
“Take the forty keys from her pants and go open the forty treasury doors. The white falcon is sitting on a golden scepter and the pearl that shines at night is by its side.”
Simurgh told him all of this, and then said: “Now go to the [parched] garden.”
The king’s son arrived there and said: “Here is a very nice garden full of flowers.”
To the flowering garden he said: “This one is completely dry.”
The prince cut off the water from the flowering garden and opened it to the parched garden.
He passed the crooked bridge and said: “What a straight bridge!”
He went and reached the crooked gate,
He said: “What a straight gate!”
From there he went [and saw] the grass in front of the dog
He passed and entered the castle of the queen with forty-meter hair whose eyes were open.
He wrapped her hair around the forty pillars and secured it there with forty nails.
After that he took the pearl from her feet and placed it by her head and took the one from her head and placed it by her feet.
He unbelted her pants and put the inner pants on top and the top pants underneath.
Forty keys were attached to her belt; he took them and ented the forty treasury doors.
The prince entered, took the white falcon, took the pearl that shines at night, and left.
When the prince came out with the white falcon, the white falcon cried out and the [queen with] forty-meter hair woke up.
She tried to get up but found her hair was attached to the forty columns.
She tried to turn over but because of the nails she could not free herself.
She said: “O almond-blossom horse!”
"Hold him!"
He [the horse] said: “Hey, I won’t hold him.”
“You didn’t give me grass, bur [rather] gave me bones; the king’s son gave me grass and took the bone away!”
She said: “O almond-blossom dog!”
"Hold him!"
He [the dog] said: “You gave me grass; he took the grass away and put bones in front of me.”
"I won't hold him."
He went to the crooked gate.
Forty-Meter called out: “O crooked gate, hold him!”
It said: “You, Forty-Meter, called me ‘the crooked gate,’ while the king’s son called me ‘straight’—why would I hold him?”
He reached the crooked gate
Forty-Meter said: “O crooked bridge, hold the king’s son!”
It said: “Forty-Meter, you called me crooked, while the king’s son called me ‘straight bridge.’”
He reached the parched garden.
Forty-Meter said: “O parched garden, hold him!”
It said: “Hey, Forty-Meter!”
“You called me parched, he called me flowering!” He reached the garden full of flowers.
Forty-Meter said: “O flowering garden, hold that one!”
The flowering garden said: “I will not hold him; in fact I am parched, yet you say I am full of flowers!”
The prince escaped, crossed several steppes and deserts, and went to the place where Simurgh had taken him.
Simurgh brought him back down to her place.
He stayed there one night, then left Simurgh’s place, hurried through several steppes and deserts, came to the house of the red devil, and took that fairy away.
He loaded up all his [the red devil’s] flocks and wealth and left to go to the white devil.
He took that fairy with him and packed up her wealth and flocks too.
She had a hunting dog, which they took as well and left.
They crossed several steppes and deserts and came to the road [labeled] “you will return,” [where] he saw that his brothers had not written any message on the stone.
Then he left all his belongings and the fairies there in a tent, and set off himself down the road “you will return”; the dog followed him.
He reached a city where one of his brothers was a water porter, one brother cooked heads, and one brother carried wood on his bare back.
He went to the one who was cooking heads and said [to his boss]: “How much does my brother owe you?”
He said: “One hundred rupees.”
He released his brother and went to the one who carried water for a shopkeeper. He said [to the shopkeeper]: “How much does my brother owe you?”
He said: “One hundred and fifty rupees.” He gave him one hundred and fifty rupees and went to the one who carried wood on his bare back for a shopkeeper.
He gave him one hundred rupees to release [his brother], and took him. He got clothes (?) for all three and said to them: “Well, brothers!”
“You were the king’s beloveds.”
“He gave you so many horses and so much food—what did you do with them?”
He set off with them in front and reached the place where the fairies, flocks, and wealth [were left].
One of the fairies he gave to his brother, another fairy he gave to another brother.
He packed up his flocks and wealth and they left. They crossed several steppes and deserts and came to a plain where there was a village.
The brother who had brought the fairies said: “Let’s go to this village.” They said: “No, let’s pitch our tents on the plain and stay.”
They pitched their tents and stayed.
At night they brought out a daggar, tied it to the entrance to the tent, and called: “Hey brother!”
“A robber has attacked us!”
He jumped out of bed and hit the dagger, which cut off both his legs at the knee.
In the morning the brothers got up and surrounded him; they tore out both his eyes and placed them in his hands and abandoned him there. [More from French than from Wakhi]
He said: "Hey brothers!"
“All these flocks and wealth are yours, just take me with you!”
"Take me to my mother!"
“Take me to my mother, and I won’t ask anything more of you!”
They didn't take him.
The dog stayed with him.
The dog went and brought him bread from the village.
He sobbed and said: “O God, cure me!” [French, or maybe] “O God, hold me a little bit more” [someone else's English translation from Wakhi]
“Restore me to my old form!”
“Take me back to where I was!”
In a dream he saw someone telling him: “Hey, young man!”
“Hold your dog’s tail and take your eyes with you.”
“In front of you will be the spring of desires.”
“When you reach the source, splash your face three times with water from the spring of desires, and your eyes will become healthy again.”
“Three more times rub your knees with water from the spring of desires and you will be cured.”
The king’s son took hold of the dog’s tale and the dog led him to the edge of the spring of wishes.
With the water from the spring of desires, he touched his eyes three times.
He was cured; three times he rubbed his knees and he was cured.
He became a young man as he was before.
He got up, took his dog, and walked off happily.
He crossed several steppes and deserts and reached his father’s kingdom. He went and said: “O mother, hide me, don’t show me to anyone!”
The three brothers brought the white falcon and the fairies and their father was very pleased with them. [He said:] “Did you never see your despised brother?”
They said: “We never saw him, God only knows what desert he died in.” Suddenly Forty-Meter appeared on horseback and called out: “O king, come out!”
The king came out and said: “Well, Forty-Meter!”
“How are you?”
“What’s going on?”
She said: “Go get your son who took my white falcon and the pearl that shines at night—I will ask them how he captured them and brought them here.”
He called his sons; one son came before the queen with forty-meter hair and greeted her.
The queen with forty-meter hair said: “How did you bring my white falcon and my pearl that shines at night?”
He said: “Just like that, I went and brought them.” She said: “No, your words are lies, for I have my signs and you have not mentioned them.”
"I do not accept it."
This son of the king could not respond, and she cut his nose with a dagger.
She said to the king: “Bring another son, who can name my signs.”
The king went and brought another son.

The queen with forty-meter hair asked him: “How did you bring my white falcon and my pearl that shines at night?” He said: “Like this: I went, and I brought them.” She said: “His words are lies,” and cut his hand with a dagger.
She said: “O king, don’t joke [with me]—bring your son!”
The king went and brought another son.
She asked: “How did you bring my white falcon and my pearl that shines at night?”
He said: “I went, and somehow I brought them back.” She said: “Your words are wrong,” and cut his feet.
She said: “King, you are joking with me—you cannot find your own son?”
He said: “I have one despised son, who disappeared.” [But] an old woman there had seen him.
The old woman said to the king: “Give me something and I will find him.”
The king gave the old woman plenty of wealth.
She said: “O king!”
“Your son is with his mother.” The king went to his son and said: “Now you’ve ruined us!”

“The queen with forty-meter hair has come to me, [saying:] ‘Your son took my white falcon and my pearl that shines at night.’” “Did you ask them how they got this white falcon and the pearl that shines at night and how they brought them from Forty-Meter’s [castle]?”
“They were your beloveds, you baked them ritual bread [pʈok], gave them horses, gave them rifles—but now they cannot deliver you from Forty-Meter?”
Finally he had no choice but to get up.
Regretfully saddled his horse, and came riding to Forty-Meter.
He greeted her and said: “O Forty-Meter, what do you have to say?"
She said: "Did you bring my white falcon?"
He said: "Yes, I brought it".
She said: “And by what signs did you bring it?”
He said: “You have these signs: one garden filled with flowers, and you call the flowering garden ‘parched,’ and a parched garden which you call ‘flowering.’”
“I cut the water from the flowering one and opened it to the parched garden.”
“You called the bridge ‘crooked,’ I called it ‘straight bridge.’”
“When I reached your gate, you called it ‘crooked gate,’ [but] I called it ‘straight gate.’”

“Then I went to the almond-blossom horse with a bone in front of him, and in front of the almond-blossom dog was grass. I took the bone from the almond blossom horse and gave it to the dog; I took the grass from the almond-blossom dog and gave it to the horse.”
“I entered your castle and your eyes were open—I took your hair and tied it to your forty pillars. There was a pearl by your head.”
“You were wearing forty [pairs of] pants…” She said: “Enough, these were in fact my signs.”
“Now I will marry you.” The queen with forty-meter hair married him; his father set him on the royal throne and said: “May this throne be blessed for you.” He attained the throne and good fortune.
